div.p: Greetings. Your diligence accuses me of sin; for a long time ago I received the description of the Muscovite or Polish battle from Augsburg and did not share it. I am sending back your description and I thank you.

Meanwhile, it is written to me that the churches will soon send a delegate from Krakow to us and to the Genevans regarding various questions (I am pleased, but it is a lot of work for me, which otherwise prepares me for many other tasks) and that the Muscovites have received support from the Tatars with 30,000 horsemen and are preparing for a new battle, etc.
Many and astonishing prodigies from the sky appear everywhere in Poland, etc. May the Lord have mercy on us and on them.

The assembly has begun in Baden; but I have nothing certain yet about the Clarens cause; many predict bad omens; I wish the matter would turn out better than it has so far. If we are to atone and be ruined, there are good means for it.

The pride and arrogance [of those people] ascend to heaven; there is no end to their threats. Perhaps Vergerius has reached you; he diligently inquired what the envoy of Philip had done among the Rhaetians; I explained the matter to him as faithfully as I could. You will hear more from him; he seems to be already losing his mind and almost acting like a child.
The book of Brentius has been returned to me, vast and bitter, perplexed and most maliciously written, etc. My affairs grow by the hour, and my strength decreases.

But it has seemed good to God my Father, who, if He is with me by His grace, I ask for nothing more in the world. Otherwise, I have not been very strong for 8 days, being able to do nothing at all, and my weakness greatly hinders me in all my matters.

But it pleases the Lord, and so it pleases me, etc. From Frankfurt, I have never had more leisure; few letters, scarcely 10 or 12, have been brought; for because of the plague, few have come. But it has subsided there; the school has also returned to Heidelberg.

The German princes have issued a document stating the reasons why they do not want to accept the Council of Trent, in German, etc. In your last letters, you write true riddles; I have never seen the Count of Helfenstein, and he has set out for Rome with a large retinue, etc., nor did he come to Zurich.
To the most excellent man, Mr. Johannes Fabricius, minister of the Church of Chur, my esteemed and beloved lord and brother. Chur.
